data.title: Pasting code destroys indentation of both the pasted code and nearby lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
jsx|Twe|0.0.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Start with code that looks like the following:

```
describe('This is a test', () => {
  it('handles addTag()', (done) => {
    let tagUserUpdated = tagUser.updateField([User.USER_PREFERENCES, User.PREFERENCES_TAGS_SELECTED], 'Tag 2|Tag 1')
    .afterUpdateSuccess()
    const stateTagUpdateSuccess = setStatusMessage(
      clearUserFetching(User.setCurrentUser(stateTagUser, tagUserUpdated), tagUserUpdated), userComponentText.userUpdated
    )
    let store = createStore(testUserState, stateTagUser, applyMiddleware(thunkMiddleware))
    nock(process.env.TEST_URL).put('/users/' + userTestData[User.USER_ID]).reply(200, {})
    testAsync(store, stateTagUpdateStart, stateTagUpdateSuccess, done)
    tagUser.setSelectedTag(store.dispatch, 'Tag 1')
  })
})

```

2. copy the 2nd line, and past it before the last line. The last line will be indented two spaces to match (presumably) the code that was pasted. This is a simple example, there are lots of other broken cases. Cutting and pasting code fragments is now significantly less productive than before. This seems to be a recent regression.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Middle click on Windows taskbar entry does not open a new window
data.body:

This is standard behavior of windows applications and allmost all applications behave this way.

data.title: Clicking on a file in Explorer view selects wrong file when revealIfOpen: true

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
If I click on a file to to open it in an editor, the selection jumps to another file. Then both files are opened and the wrongly selected file has the focus. This does not happen always but often. I reproduced it without extensions by renaming the ".vscode" user directory. Without extensions still happens but it seems not to happen as often as with all extensions activated.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. A not too small project is needed - it has to be possible to scroll the files in the Explorer view.
2. I could only reproduce it if two editors are opened side by side and enough files are opened already that the file tabs at each side do not fit in the row.
3. (Double) click different files in the Explorer view. Sometimes you can see that the selection jumps unexptectedly and the wrong file (that got the selection unexpectedly) is opened - thats the bug.

---

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---

data.title: Task list markdown not showing properly in preview tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
tslint|eg2|0.17.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `test.md` file.
2. Enter task list markdown like:
```
- [x] Hello World
- [x] list syntax required
- [x] this is a complete item
- [ ] this is an incomplete item
```
3. Open preview pressing <kbd>Ctrl+K</kbd><kbd>V</kbd> hot keys.
4. And we can see the preview for this markdown like this:
![vscode-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14850464/30005138-6e27115e-90f9-11e7-93d7-96e0ea74d226.jpg)

5. Which is not same as we see here:
- [x] Hello World
- [x] list syntax required
- [x] this is a complete item
- [ ] this is an incomplete item

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

```shell
Found 'Tyriar.sort-lines' in the marketplace.
Installing...

(node:659) DeprecationWarning: Unhandled promise rejections are deprecated. In the future, promise rejections that are not handled will terminate the Node.js process with a non-zero exit code.
```

- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

data.title: Emmet 2.0 doesn't work nice with empty custom components
data.body:
I work with vuejs, and I use components alot. Everything was fine with previous version.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write `link-list`, and press tab. 
2. Nothing happens

In previous version

1. write `link-list`, and press tab.
2. Got <link-list></link-list>

This is a huge boost for me to just write `something` and get `<something></something>`. But since emmet 2.0, I can no longer do this. Except for built in html element

data.title: Improving retention of colors when copying text
data.body: As I understand it, when copying some text VSC also copies its style along with it, in order to provide a better experience when pasting that text in a rich editor like Gmail's. I believe this feature should be improved. Currently not all colors are copied along when highlighting some text using a .tmLanguage file, and none are copied when highlighting it dynamically using the API. ## tmLanguage This is what a sample file highlighted using @sandy081's [todotasks](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=sandy081.todotasks) extension looks like, respectively inside VSC and inside Gmail's editor after pasting: ## Dynamically And this is what the same file looks when using my [Todo+](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=fabiospampinato.vscode-todo-plus) extension:

data.title: Add fuzzy search to search by symbol
data.body:
Currently on VSCode you can 'Open symbol by name' (https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/editingevolved#_open-symbol-by-name) across files by clicking Cmd+T.

However it doesn't seem to support fuzzy search.

E.g. If I have a function called `dao_get_bookings` and search for `dao ` (notice space at the end), it will not return any results. The space is counted strictly as a character meaning the search breaks down. This is a real shame as Sublime makes this effortless and frankly amazing for this use case.

data.title: Option to find conflicting (duplicate) keyboard shortcuts

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Many VSCode extensions come with their own set of keyboard shortcuts which usually do not conflict with those shipped as default with VSCode.

However, with multiple extensions installed it often happens that two or more of them register the same keyboard shortcut and since there is currently no system in place to prevent that (at least not to my knowledge) the only way to find out that there is a conflict is by actually using a shortcut and realizing it doesn't do what it's supposed to do.

I think that this feature is essential for a tool that relies so heavily on using shortcuts.

**EDIT**: Just to be clear, I am aware of the _"Show conflicts"_ option in the right-click context menu but it basically just does a search for a specific keyboard shortcut (the one that has been right-clicked on).

What I am talking about is a feature that would, for example, color all duplicate entries in _Keyboard shortcuts_ dialog red or at least warn if an extension is trying to register a shortcut that has already been declared.

data.title: [Markdown] Escaping spaces in links result in Unable to open error.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

| Extension                 | Author (truncated) | Version |
| ------------------------- | ------------------ | ------- |
| overtype                  | ada                | 0.2.0   |
| vscode-markdownlint       | Dav                | 0.10.0  |
| reg                       | ion                | 0.0.1   |
| intellij-idea-keybindings | k--                | 0.2.13  |
| PowerShell                | ms-                | 1.4.1   |
| vscode-docker             | Pet                | 0.0.16  |
| awesome-vhdl              | puo                | 0.0.1   |
| markdown-preview-enhanced | shd                | 0.2.8   |
| markdown-all-in-one       | yzh                | 0.8.3   |

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create Main.md file.

```markdown
- [File without spaces](./Foo/Bar.md "Working")
- [File with spaces](./Foo/Bar\ with\ spaces.md "Not Working")
  - Working on GitHub, Gitlab, etc.
```

2. Create Folder with 2 markdown files inside.
    - One with spaces in name ("Bar with spaces.md")
    - One without spaces in name ("Bar.md")
3. Preview Main.md file and try to click on both links.
    - File without spaces will open in editor.
    - File with spaces could not be opened.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: The terminal sometimes scrolls up a little by itself and requires the user to scroll down
data.body:
I'm not sure how to repro this but I've seen it multiple times during regular development over the weekend. Occasionally the scroll bar ends up ~5 lines above the bottom and needs me to scroll down (but still scrolls relative to this point when there's new output).

Looking at the scroll-related code it looks like I'm pointing at an internal xterm.js property and using it to scroll, that's likely the cause.

data.title: Exclude VM scripts via skipFiles
data.body:
Hi,

I'd like to make a feature request to exclude 'VM Scripts' that are dynamically created with `eval()` from the VS Code debugger as suggested by @roblourens [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46013729/vscode-debugger-exclude-node-vm-files?noredirect=1#comment78993320_46013729).

To make progress immediately, if a knowledgeable contributor can identify the code in the source, us open source users can start the grunt work of implementation.

[Some reading](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17367560/chrome-development-tool-vm-file-from-javascript), [relevant discussion](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29897750/is-it-possible-to-blackbox-all-vm-scripts-in-chrome-debugger).

Thank you.

data.title: VStudioCode seems to create gigabytes of write load
data.body:
Is there a way to stop VSCode trashing harddirves/ssds? As soon as I activate any VSC window and create some input events like moving the mouse over the window etc., it's going to write about 50-500kb/sec to my drive and I have absolutely no clue why/what it's writing but it sums up to gigabytes of write load in a very few hours of regular usage of VSC.

I use the process explorer tool from sysinternals to display the amount of data written.


- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open VSC and load a project or even just create a new empty file
2.that's it

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Regular expression search help / documentation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

I find the regular expression search very useful because it includes operators (like matching word boundaries).  One is not limited to the POSIX syntax for an RE.

I find that I have to guess at the available operators (perhaps I do not look in the right places) and try things that work in python or perl.  For example, '\b' (from python3) matches the boundary of an alpha string.

I would like to go to documentation (perhaps "Advanced Editing" or "Search" where I could find the regular expression syntax for vsCode.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn on the regular expression option in a vsCode search box.
2. Try things until something works.
